bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jessie Daniel Ames, May 27, 1930

div1.p: Agramonte informs Mrs. Ames about her husband's actions and responsibilities with the yellow fever board in Cuba, enclosing answers to questions she has posed.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jessie Daniel Ames, May 27, 1930
div1.p:
COPY
May 27th, 1930 Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames,
Atlanta, Ga.
Dear Madam:

Have just received your letter of the 21st inst. with
various statements and documents, which I hasten to answer.

I am very glad that I am not obliged to say that the
events referred to, “happened so long ago” that I cannot remember,
for the facts are as clearly in my mind today as when they took
place 30 years ago, and having lived here all the time, in contin-
uous contact with the scene of our labors, every detail is vividly
impressed upon my memory.

Particularly of Dr. Ames, of whom I have been recently
speaking with one of his relatives, Capt. Beyers of the S. S.
Parismina, I have most distinct and pleasant recollection. Dr.
Ames was very well thought of by everyone who knew him and I,
personally, was much attached to him from the time that I met him
at the Military Hospital No. 1 until he left Cuba, early in 1901.

His work, in the early part of the Board's experiments
was principally in the city of Havana, visiting and disposing the
removal to hospital of yellow fever cases and the disinfection of
supposedly infected areas; at that time he was considered immune
to yellow fever, himself claiming either to having had the dis-
ease or much contact with cases in New Orleans. I do not remem-
ber exactly on what basis his immunity was founded, but I do
remember that it was for this reason and his evident familiarity
with the disease, that he was detailed at Columbia Barracks to
take care of the experimental cases. He certainly had excellent
judgment and although the cases were all officially confirmed
by a special expert board, he was the first who came in contact
with them and made the earliest diagnosis.

Dr. Ames had no connection whatever with the yellow
fever Board before the establishment of Camp Lazear; he attended
the cases of Drs. Carroll and Lazear when they came down with
the fever, in the regular course of duty at Columbia Barracks
and because he was reputed immune to the disease; for this same
reason, when Camp Lazear was set up, he was entrusted by the
Board with the administration of the Camp, the payment of the
Spaniards hired as day laborers for the later purpose of the
experiments, provision of food, equipment, quarterly, etc. for
the “subjects” and for the military guard maintained there, but
he had absolutely nothing to do with the experiments, with the
selection of the men, their observation, their inoculation or
the keeping of their records, etc. His scientific services be-
gan when a case was developed; as soon as high temperature or
the least symptom appeared, the case was removed from Camp Lazear
to special individual barracks, two miles from the Camp, near
the Columbia Barracks Hospital, where it was placed under Dr. Ames'
charge until his final recovery. They all recovered, a fact that
we all thought was “a feather in his cap”..

With regard to his alleged attack of yellow fever in
February, 1901, I must say there was much discrepancy of opinion.
I, for one, never believed he had yellow fever, though I think
it went as such in the records. In the first place, it was very
difficult to trace the source of his infection and by that time
Maj. Gorgas had a very good hold of the situation, all cases in
Havana and vicinity being very closely watched and recorded; be-
sides this, the clinical picture was not very clear and some of
the symptoms might well have been attributed to other causes.
There was a bare possibility, given his asserted immunity, that he
really had a second attack of yellow fever, of a mild or a typical
character.

I have endeavored to answer the questions you sent me to
the best of my ability and am taking the liberty of enclosing a
copy of an article I wrote fifteen years ago, that might interest
you.

I am afraid my information may not meet your expectations
but I know that you would not want anything except the truth and I
certainly would make no statements otherwise, much as I would be
happy to see some sort of recognition made in your favor.
